5.3 Ethics and Casuistry

Spanish Scholasticism reflects a long-standing tradition of teleology,
which looked to the final cause of human conduct. Humans bore the
image of God, including the rationality Suárez saw in all
mortals. These beings could be moved by reason to right conduct,
individually and in politics. (Pink 2022: 279–305). Spanish
Scholastics like Bartolomé de Medina and Azpilcueta were deeply
concerned with casuistry, the means of guiding human conduct. Others,
including some Protestants, used similar approaches. Casuistry can be
found in the discussion of such issues as lying through “mental
reservation”. Cases of conscience were compiled to help in the
guidance of souls, especially in avoidance of sin.

The uncertainties of life led to the development of the idea of
“probabilism,” looking to what was most likely when
certainty could not be obtained. Medina was a pioneer in this,
claiming that, when in doubt, one might discern the more probable
opinion. This, in turn, permitted choosing the “more probable
option”—or even a less probable choice—in moral
decision making. It looks as if the first traces can already be found
in writings of Vitoria and Alonso de la Vera Cruz (Egío
García 2022). Probabilism was also used by some of the Jesuits
who were active in South America and Nueva España when they had
to cope with problems of the treatment of Indigenous peoples and with
African slavery, e.g., Diego de Avendaño (1594–1688)
(Avendaño 1668; Haar & Kaufmann 2023: Kap. 2.4.2.,
4.2.).

More strictly, some theologians said to adopt only the safest course
of action. Critics of such approaches, including Blaise Pascal,
denounced them for laxity, leading to use of “casuistry”
as a negative term (Schüssler 2022).
